media.caption: Bobby Jones drives on the unfinished Augusta National as Alister MacKenzie and Jones work on the course in April 1932.

text.headline: Augusta national golf club
text.text:
In July 1931, banner headlines in newspapers across the country trumpeted the news: Bobby Jones was building a course in Augusta, and Alister MacKenzie would be the primary architect.
Jones & MacKenzie: Two of one mind in regard to National

text.headline: Magnolia Lane
text.text:
Magnolia Lane extends from the entrance gate to the clubhouse. The large magnolia trees that line both sides of the 330-yard road date to the late 1850s. Magnolia Lane was first paved in 1947.
Story: Augusta National beefs up security on Magnolia Lane

text.headline: Founders circle
text.text:
Founders Circle is at the base of the flagpole in front of the clubhouse. Two plaques there honor the Masters' founders Bobby Jones and Clifford Roberts.
Video: The flower bed at Founders Circle

text.headline: Clubhouse
text.text:
It’s the most recognizable landmark in American golf. Built in 1854 by indigo plantation owner Dennis Redmond, it is considered the first cement house constructed in the South.
Read more:  Inside golf's most famous clubhouse | A landmark of American golf | Clubhouse is home to National treasures 
Slideshow: The clubhouse at ANGC
See a 360-degree panoramic view of the big oak behind the clubhouse

text.headline: Putting Green
text.text: Located behind the No. 1 tee, this green is used by players for last-minute short-putt warm-ups. It is maintained at the same speed as the greens on the main course.

media.caption: Bubba Watson, Webb Simpson and Rickie Fowler on the No. 8 green during the Par-3 Contest at the 2014 Masters.

text.headline: Par-3 Course
text.text:
The Par-3 Course was designed by architect George Cobb, with help from Clifford Roberts, and constructed in 1958. The nine-hole course plays to a par of 27 and measures 1,060 yards.
The Par-3 Contest is held on the Wednesday before the Masters Tournament, and participation is optional. Since the event's beginning in 1960, no player has won the Par-3 Contest and then gone on to win the green jacket in the same year.

Read more about the Par-3 Contest
See a 360-degree panoramic view

media.caption: Arnold Palmer tees off on No. 1 during the 2004 Masters.

text.headline: No. 1 tee
text.text:
The slight dogleg right is not the easiest tee shot golfers will face. Carrying the fairway bunker will require a drive of 300 yards, and shorter hitters will face an uphill shot to the undulating green.
Read: Gallery guards cherish relationships made at No. 1
Course Tour: Hole 1 - Tea Olive
See a 360-degree panoramic view of the No. 1 tee

text.headline: Main Scoreboard
text.text:
The main scoreboard lists every player, his residence and his score for each hole. Black numbers mean par; red is for birdie; bold red for eagle; green for bogey; bold green for double bogey or higher.
See a 360-degree panoramic view of the main scoreboard area

text.headline: No. 1 Green
text.text: Course Tour: Hole 1

media.caption: Bubba Watson tees up on No. 2 during the first round of the 2013 Masters Tournament.

text.headline: No. 2 Tee
text.text:
A slight draw off the tee sets up a chance to reach the par-5 green in two. Bunkers in front of the green often come into play.
Read: Second hole proves favorable for birdies despite length
Course Tour: Hole 2 - Pink Dogwood

media.caption: Patrons wait for golfers on the second green during the third round of the 2013 Masters Tournament.

text.headline: No. 2 Green
text.text:
A slight draw off the tee sets up a chance to reach the par-5 green in two. Bunkers in front of the green often come into play.
Read: Second hole proves favorable for birdies despite length
Course Tour: Hole 2 - Pink Dogwood

media.caption: Charles Howell III tees off on No. 3 during the 2003 Masters.

text.headline: No. 3 Tee
text.text:
Most players opt for position off the tee with a long iron or a fairway wood. The small green, which slopes from right to left, is not entirely visible from the fairway.
Course Tour: Hole 3 - Flowering Peach

media.caption: Shingo Katayama of Japan hits to the third green during the 2006 Masters.

text.headline: No. 3 Green
text.text:
Most players opt for position off the tee with a long iron or a fairway wood. The small green, which slopes from right to left, is not entirely visible from the fairway.
Course Tour: Hole 3 - Flowering Peach

media.caption: Mike Weir tees off on No. 4 during the 2004 Masters.

text.headline: No. 4 Tee
text.text:
This tough par-3 requires a long-iron shot to the green, which is guarded by a pair of bunkers.
Read: Par-3s on front nine offer test
Course Tour: Hole 4 - Flowering Crabapple

media.caption: Graeme McDowell, foreground, walks up to the No. 4 green as Jason Day, of Australia, hits from the bunker during Tuesday practice rounds of the 2011 Masters.

text.headline: No. 4 Green
text.text:
This tough par-3 requires a long-iron shot to the green, which is guarded by a pair of bunkers.
Read: Par-3s on front nine offer test
Course Tour: Hole 4 - Flowering Crabapple

media.caption: Phil Mickelson tees off on No. 5 during the final round Sunday April 13. 2003 at the Masters.

text.headline: No. 5 Tee
text.text:
The deep fairway bunkers on the left require a carry of 315 yards around the dogleg. Large humps in the green make it a challenging putting surface.
Course Tour: Hole 5 - Magnolia

text.headline: No. 5 Green
text.text:
The deep fairway bunkers on the left require a carry of 315 yards around the dogleg. Large humps in the green make it a challenging putting surface.
Course Tour: Hole 5 - Magnolia

text.headline: No. 6 Tee
text.text:
This downhill par-3 usually requires no more than a medium iron to the large, undulating green. Put the ball on the wrong part of the green, however, and a three-putt is likely.
Read: Augusta National's No. 6 is unusual par-3
Course Tour: Hole 6 - Juniper
See a 360-degree panoramic view of the 6th tee

text.headline: No. 6 Green
text.text:
This downhill par-3 usually requires no more than a medium iron to the large, undulating green. Put the ball on the wrong part of the green, however, and a three-putt is likely.
Read: Augusta National's No. 6 is unusual par-3
Course Tour: Hole 6 - Juniper
See a 360-degree panoramic view of the 6th tee

text.headline: No. 7 Tee
text.text:
The new tee installed in 2002 puts a driver back into most players hands. The hole features a narrow fairway to an elevated, well-bunkered green.
Course Tour: Hole 7 - Pampas

text.headline: No. 7 Green
text.text:
The new tee installed in 2002 puts a driver back into most players hands. The hole features a narrow fairway to an elevated, well-bunkered green.
Course Tour: Hole 7 - Pampas

text.headline: No. 8 Tee
text.text:
A large fairway bunker makes this par-5 difficult to reach in two shots. A blind uphill shot awaits those who are tempted to go for it in two.
Read: No. 8 could be easier to play than walk
Augusta's par-5s still put excitement in play 80 years later
Course Tour: Hole 8 - Yellow Jasmine

text.headline: No. 8 Green
text.text:
A large fairway bunker makes this par-5 difficult to reach in two shots. A blind uphill shot awaits those who are tempted to go for it in two.
Read: No. 8 could be easier to play than walk
Augusta's par-5s still put excitement in play 80 years later
Course Tour: Hole 8 - Yellow Jasmine

text.headline: No. 9 Tee
text.text:
The severely sloped green makes par a challenge. Accuracy off the tee is required, and approach shots that are short of the target often roll off the green.
Course Tour: Hole 9 - Carolina Cherry
See a 360-degree panoramic view of the area between No. 1 and No. 9

text.headline: No. 9 Green
text.text:
The severely sloped green makes par a challenge. Accuracy off the tee is required, and approach shots that are short of the target often roll off the green.
Course Tour: Hole 9 - Carolina Cherry
See a 360-degree panoramic view of the area between No. 1 and No. 9

media.caption: Aaron Baddeley hits off the tenth tee during the 2011 Masters.

text.headline: No. 10 Tee
text.text:
Historically the toughest hole at Augusta National, the tee shot requires a hard hook to gain extra distance. Drives that go too far right will leave a long second shot; if they go too far left, trees are a problem.
Read: Fans track down Bubba Watson's spot on No. 10
Photos: Scene of Bubba Watson's famous shot
Course Tour: Hole 10 - Camellia

media.caption: Jeffrey Overton and Aaron Baddeley on the tenth green during the 2011 Masters.

text.headline: No. 10 Green
text.text:
Historically the toughest hole at Augusta National, the tee shot requires a hard hook to gain extra distance. Drives that go too far right will leave a long second shot; if they go too far left, trees are a problem.
Read: Fans track down Bubba Watson's spot on No. 10
Photos: Scene of Bubba Watson's famous shot
Course Tour: Hole 10 - Camellia

media.caption: Tiger Woods follows his tee shot on No. 11 at the 2005 Masters.

text.headline: No. 11 Tee
text.text:
The start of Amen Corner is the most difficult hole in recent years because of its added length. A slight fade off the tee is necessary to reach the fairway. The greenside pond is more of a factor, because players have longer shots into the green.
Read: Changes for 2002 built up No. 11's difficulty
Amen Corner saw history the year it was named
Course Tour: Hole 11 - White Dogwood

media.caption: Kenny Perry and his caddie on the green near the lake on No. 11 at the 2010 Masters.

text.headline: No. 11 Green
text.text:
The start of Amen Corner is the most difficult hole in recent years because of its added length. A slight fade off the tee is necessary to reach the fairway. The greenside pond is more of a factor, because players have longer shots into the green.
Read: Changes for 2002 built up No. 11's difficulty
Amen Corner saw history the year it was named
Course Tour: Hole 11 - White Dogwood

media.caption: Patrons wait for golfers on the 11th green and 12th tee during the 2013 Masters.

text.headline: No. 12 Tee
text.text:
The shortest hole is a bear to play because of swirling winds. Its usually a medium- or short-iron shot to a narrow green that is protected by Raes Creek in front and azaleas behind.
Read: No. 12 can blow away hopes of jacket
Course Tour: Hole 12 - Golden Bell
See a 360-degree panoramic view of No. 12

media.caption: 12th green, 2011 Masters.

text.headline: No. 12 Green
text.text:
The shortest hole is a bear to play because of swirling winds. Its usually a medium- or short-iron shot to a narrow green that is protected by Raes Creek in front and azaleas behind.
Read: No. 12 can blow away hopes of jacket
Course Tour: Hole 12 - Golden Bell
See a 360-degree panoramic view of No. 12

media.caption: Tiger Woods and Mark O'Meara on the 13th tee during the 2012 Masters.

text.headline: No. 13 Tee
text.text:
The classic risk-reward hole became more challenging with a new tee added in 2002. A slight draw is required to get into position for the second shot to the par-5, but a tributary of the creek catches shots that come up short.
Read: 13th hole known for beauty, drama
Augusta's par-5s still put excitement in play 80 years later
Course Tour: Hole 13 - Azalea
See a 360-degree panoramic view of the area between No. 13 and 14

media.caption: Martin Kaymer and Alex Cejka on the 13th green during the 2011 Masters.

text.headline: No. 13 Green
text.text:
The classic risk-reward hole became more challenging with a new tee added in 2002. A slight draw is required to get into position for the second shot to the par-5, but a tributary of the creek catches shots that come up short.
Read: 13th hole known for beauty, drama
Augusta's par-5s still put excitement in play 80 years later
Course Tour: Hole 13 - Azalea
See a 360-degree panoramic view of the area between No. 13 and 14

media.caption: A fore caddie warns of approaching golfers on No. 14 during the third round of the 2013 Masters Tournament.

text.headline: No. 14 Tee
text.text:
Its the only hole on the course without a bunker, but a severe green provides plenty of problems. Players often have to hit driver instead of a 3-wood, and a sloping fairway kicks shots into trouble on the right. Large undulations on the green make this the trickiest to putt.
Course Tour: Hole 14 - Chinese Fir
See a 360-degree panoramic view of the No. 14 tee

media.caption: Sergio Garcia, K.J. Choi and David Toms on the 14th green during the 2012 Masters.

text.headline: No. 14 Green
text.text:
Its the only hole on the course without a bunker, but a severe green provides plenty of problems. Players often have to hit driver instead of a 3-wood, and a sloping fairway kicks shots into trouble on the right. Large undulations on the green make this the trickiest to putt.
Course Tour: Hole 14 - Chinese Fir
See a 360-degree panoramic view of the area between No. 13 and 14

media.caption: Angel Cabrera, right, and Jhonattan Vegas prepare to hit from the No. 15 tee at the 2011 Masters.

text.headline: No. 15 Tee
text.text:
Changes made in the last decade make reaching this par-5 hole in two shots a challenge, but plenty of birdies will be had. A pond guards the green in front, but those who lay up face a hard shot from a downhill lie.
Read: No. 15 home to famous approach shot, double eagle
Course Tour: Hole 15 - Fire Thorn
See a 360-degree panoramic view of No. 15

media.caption: Tiger Woods walks up to the 15th green during the 2010 Masters.

text.headline: No. 15 Green
text.text:
Changes made in the last decade make reaching this par-5 hole in two shots a challenge, but plenty of birdies will be had. A pond guards the green in front, but those who lay up face a hard shot from a downhill lie.
Read: No. 15 home to famous approach shot, double eagle
Course Tour: Hole 15 - Fire Thorn
See a 360-degree panoramic view of No. 15

media.caption: Vijay Singh tees off on the 16th hole during the 2006 Masters.

text.headline: No. 16 Tee
text.text:
This par-3 requires anything from a short- to medium-iron shot. The green is the holes main defense; being below the hole is a must. The back bunker and a pond on the left also pose hazards.
Read: No. 16 site of many holes-in-one
Course Tour: Hole 16 - Redbud
See a 360-degree panoramic view of the No. 16

text.headline: No. 16 Green
text.text:
This par-3 requires anything from a short- to medium-iron shot. The green is the holes main defense; being below the hole is a must. The back bunker and a pond on the left also pose hazards.
Read: No. 16 site of many holes-in-one
Course Tour: Hole 16 - Redbud
See a 360-degree panoramic view of the No. 16

media.caption: 17th tee during the 2014 Masters.

text.headline: No. 17 Tee
text.text:
For most players it's a short-iron second shot into a rock-hard green.
Read:  Augusta National's Eisenhower Tree removed after storm damage
Big Three have differing views on changed No. 17
Course Tour: Hole 17 - Nandina

media.caption: No. 17 green during the 2013 Masters.

text.headline: No. 17 Green
text.text:
For most players it's a short-iron second shot into a rock-hard green.
Read:  Augusta National's Eisenhower Tree removed after storm damage
Big Three have differing views on changed No. 17
Course Tour: Hole 17 - Nandina

media.caption: Arnold Palmer tees off on 18 during the 2002 Masters.

text.headline: No. 18 Tee
text.text:
The closing hole has become a 465-yard challenge with the extension of the tee in 2002. An accurate drive is a must, and an expanded bunker complex requires a clout of 335 yards to carry. Trees to the left of the bunkers prevent a bailout on that side, and the elevated green is guarded by bunkers.
Read: Changes since '02: How 18 plays now 
Fans stake out seats at 18th
Course Tour: Hole 18 - Holly

media.caption: Tiger Woods, right, putts on the 18th green during the 2012 Masters.

text.headline: No. 18 Green
text.text:
The closing hole has become a 465-yard challenge with the extension of the tee in 2002. An accurate drive is a must, and an expanded bunker complex requires a clout of 335 yards to carry. Trees to the left of the bunkers prevent a bailout on that side, and the elevated green is guarded by bunkers.
Read: Changes since '02: How 18 plays now 
Fans stake out seats at 18th
Course Tour: Hole 18 - Holly
